title: When you say "ggez", you're are legitimately being an A-hole.
body:
Edit: It was recently made clear to me that the title says "you're are". That's autocorrect for you. Ignore it.

___________________________________________

"Gg" means "good game". By that, you're saying that everyone played well and it was a good match.

"Ez" means "easy". By that, you're implying that you stomped them, they did terribly, and it was easy for you to win the match because of how terrible they did.

"You did well" and "you did horribly" aren't the same thing at all.

So when you say "ggez" you're saying:

"Good game, everyone played well! SIKE! Y'all are horrible and I stomped your asses."

So pick one, gg, or ez, because whenever you say "ggez" you're just being a smug bastard.

show me one riot comment where they say you can be banned for it. all they have said on the topic is that it is reportable, but you have to do a lot more than just say "ggez" to be punished.

Anything that is reportable is by definition punishable, the only variables are how much they weight in the scale. If you are under review a report for gg ez might be what tips the scale, which means you were punished for it. Also Riot has often made statements suggesting they take into account how often a behavior leads to a report.

While on the topic, I never really understood why winning teams often say "GG!" in all chat. If everyone played well, including the losing team, then why did they lose? If they had actually played well, it follows then that they would have won.

You realize people can play well and still lose, right? Have you never had a close game that was enjoyable because it was challenging?

I say GG after any game that wasn't a stomp.

It does happen, but most of the game where gg is said aren't these close games.

Close games in general happen less and less.

What usually happens is this:

1-2 people do badly (tilted, poor player from bad matchmaking, autofilled, DC'd, bad game, etc)

The people that face those "bad players" in-lane snowball

The ones that snowballed say "gg"

Regardless it's supposed to be similar to a handshake at the end of a match. Whether you did well or poorly you're supposed to shake their hands, and then accept responsibility for the loss and work to make more future matches into a win. 

That's what it's _supposed_ to be, at least. Not so much the case in practice, though, unfortunately. Turns out, when you give some people anonymity their sense of sportsmanship goes away along with their identity.
well here's the real question then, are people nice because they want too be or because society expects us to be to nice/sportsmanlike?

Ooh, sociology. Now that one's a harder question to answer because I feel like that one will most often depend on your personal philosophy on the nature of man, with philosophers and studies taken up to defend your stance. The addition of anonymity can be seen as a break from society and thus can be how they truly are, or they can take that as opportunity to be something they're not, depending on how you want to look at it.

I think most people are generally crude at their core. Tolerant to those they get to know and friendly+ if compatible. I think those who are genuinely nice are in the minority at the very least. How long it takes for these phases to occur/pass depend on how compatible the two people. That's just my take on it anyway. I for one am not someone who is nice at heart but I'm at least polite as I believe in treating others as you wish to be treated. Depending on how true nature vs nurture is though, I'm sure I would have been considered a war criminal or of something similar had I been born in a different time period or area. Had I been given the opportunity.
